aboutMe:
Hello there! I am Scottie T. Fado-Bristow.

As a Software Engineer, I have cut my teeth on multiple live service games. I've helped prototype ideas during incubation, planned out scalable live-service systems, and helped the UI and Design teams shine by creating optimized and simplified Unity UI containers.

I have a massive passion for games; most of my work is amongst plushes and figures of my favorite games. I spend my week going to Fighting Game Locals, playing Pool with friends, and writing. If you ever have a few hours to kill, I will gladly pull out my documents for games and narratives and ramble to you.

If you have any questions or would like additional information, feel free to contact me at tfbscott@gmail.com.

gallery.desc: Gif of Gameplay, showing Kickers and UI I maintained.
I built an optimized scroll container that can scroll over hundreds of items while maintaining our target framerate.
The shop UI was built to ensure it could easily scale as more shop items were designed and added.
I handled both the backend and frontend for systems such as Unit, Equipment, and Skill progression.
Using a custom Behavior Tree system, enemies could be given custom AI with very little hassle.

gallery.desc: Unity Nav-Meshes were used to let multiple enemies path around the screen.
Multiple layers of nav-meshes were used to allow enemies to move over/under each other. The Nav-Mesh was also updated to only ever include open rooms.

projects.name: Match 3 Prototype
projects.desc: A deterministic Match 3 demo used during RfP

gallery.desc: The puzzle controller took in an action, such as swapping two pieces or replacing a piece, asynchronously updated the board, and then returned a list of snapshots that a Monobehavior would lerp through.
An independent class would analyze the board, looking for possible moves. This algorithm only looked at pieces dirtied by the previous action, reducing the needed calculations.

projects.name: Custom Engine
projects.desc: Couch Multiplayer Shooter in a Custom C++ Engine

gallery.desc: This project was a simple couch shooter to explore how input and static libraries worked.
The codebase consists of 5 libraries, reducing compile time and ensuring independent systems stay as disconnected as possible.
The graphics pipeline and input system supported up to 16 splitscreen players at once.
The input system was modeled after Unreal's event system, letting any behavior code monitor input events for a specific input device.

projects.name: The Descent
projects.desc: Procedurally Generated Rogue-Like Shooter in UE5

gallery.desc: Enemy units used a flocking algorithm written in C++ to prevent unit collision.l
All enemies had a base behavior tree that drove if the enemy was idle, alert, attacking, or scared.
Most of the game's animations came from Mixamo's library, and UE5's animation retargeter was used to match the animations onto a distinct set of models.
To improve readability, all enemy units had a custom shader that could change the colors of distinct parts of the enemies.
The colors of this custom shader could be controlled by the player, allowing for additional color blind accessibility options.
